text.p: Following are some of the main stories in Dutch newspapers today. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
FINANCIEELE DAGBLAD
- Amsterdam stock exchange has no plans to enforce corporate compliance with recommendations to enhance shareholder say. (p.1)
- Accountancy working group calls for end to accountants' monopoly in areas other than auditing corporate accounts. (p.1)
- Amsterdam city council gains go-ahead to build controversial underground metro line after poor turn-out at referendum. (p.1)
- Growth in civil aviation boosts jobs in Amsterdam region (p.7)
- KLM says to suspend transport of radioactive material on passenger flights. (p.3)
- ABN AMRO's German holding saw profits fall in 1996 due to extra loan-loss provisions. (p.3)
- Philips to launch new CD recorder at year-end. (p.5)
- A consortium including Dutch PTT and ING looks set to lose its tender to operate 6,000 Argentinian post offices (p.5).
- Finance minister Gerrit Zalm says he will not seek to achieve a balanced budget 'at any price' during the next cabinet term. (p.7).
- Wolters Kluwer acquires U.S. legal publisher. (p.3)
DE VOLKSKRANT
- Dutch foreign minister Hans van Mierlo has refused the lower house further information on arms exports by Dutch companies (p.1)
- Dutch to reduce speed limit in urban areas to 30 kilometres an hour (p.1)
- Row over free student travel on public transport escalates within three-party coalition. (p.1)
- Investors give corporate governance recommendations a lukewarm welcome. (p.2)
- Health minister Els Borst approves four new expensive drugs for remuneration by health insurers (p.8).
DE TELEGRAAF
- KLM lifts restrictions stipulating journeys must start in the countries where tickets have been purchased, which could mean major savings for Dutch passengers. (p.1).
- Dutch want more women in the defence force (p.3).
- Dutch insurers plan to introduce environmental damages policy, claiming a world first. (p.33)
- Dutch scientific publisher E.J. Brill plans to apply for bourse listing within two months. (p.37)
ALGEMEEN DAGBLAD
- Public prosecutor launches criminal investigation into allegations airline KLM failed to carry out the required checks on a radioactive cargo it accepted for shipment. (p.1)
- Soccer club Ajax Amsterdam buys three foreign players. (p.1)
TROUW
- Justice minister Winnie Sorgdrager to seek court judgement on legality of arrests during European Summit in Amsterdam earlier this month. (p.1)

- Dutch prime minister Wim Kok did not receive the valuable gift of a Rolex watch given to other government leaders at the recent G7 summit in Denver. Germany's Helmut Kohl is to hand the present back, while Britain's Tony Blair said at the time he could not accept it. (p.1)
